LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
 Borrower  Islamic Republic of Pakistan 
   
The Proposal  This proposal comprises the following: 
 
(i)  a program cluster for the Punjab Millennium Development Goals 
Program  (PMDGP)  comprising  three  subprograms  to  improve 
health service delivery and financing; and 
(ii)  a proposed loan of $100 million equivalent for subprogram 1 of the 
PMDGP. 
 
Classification  Targeting classification: Targeted intervention—non-income Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs) 
Sector: Health, nutrition, and social protection 
Subsector: Health systems 
Themes: Inclusive social development, governance, gender and 
development 
Subthemes: Human development, financial and economic governance, 
gender equity in opportunities 
   
Environment  Category C 
Assessment 
   
Program Rationale  Punjab is the most populous province of Pakistan, with 56% of the total 
population. It has the largest provincial economic base in the country, 
accounting for over 50% of Pakistan’s gross domestic product (GDP). 
While the province has achieved robust economic growth in recent 
years, its social indicators have lagged behind those of the other South 
Asian countries. The government of Punjab (GoPb) has placed high 
priority on the attainment of MDGs, and has recently increased budget 
allocations to social sectors. The province is likely to achieve all MDGs 
except reduction of the infant mortality rate (MDG4) from 77 to 40 per 
1000 live births, and the maternal mortality ratio (MDG5) from 300 to 
140 per 100,000 live births. More serious efforts are needed to attain 
these two essential health MDGs. If they are achieved, Punjab can 
potentially  save  the  lives  of  at  least  11,000  women  and 
235,000 children by 2015. 
 
Recognizing the critical need, the GoPb has developed a health sector 
reform framework, and has sought support from the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) to accelerate attainment of the two health MDGs. At a 
broader level, it has initiated service delivery reforms as part of the 
ADB-supported Public Resource Management Program and the Punjab 
Devolved Social Services Program. The former aims to improve the 
operational efficiency of the provincial government and thereby create 
fiscal  space  for  social  service  delivery,  while  the  latter  aims  to 
strengthen  district  systems  and  develop  necessary  service  delivery 
standards  for  devolved  social  services,  including  health,  education, 
water supply, and sanitation.

ii     
ADB  has  been  committed  to  MDGs  since  2002.  The  attainment  of 
MDGs will help achieve inclusive economic growth, a key objective of 
ADB’s  long-term  strategic  framework  2008–2020  (Strategy  2020), 
which encourages ADB member countries to promote greater access to 
opportunities  by  expanding  human  capacities,  especially  for  the 
disadvantaged,  through  investments  in  education,  health,  and  basic 
social protections. In line with Strategy 2020, the PMDGP focuses on 
governance  of  health  service  delivery  and  management  of  public 
resources.  Moreover,  the  PMDGP  adopts  a  programmatic  modality, 
which  by  leveraging  policy  and  institutional  reforms  is  expected  to 
ensure  sustained  GoPb  focus  on  health  sector  needs  beyond  the 
medium term, unlike stand-alone project interventions. 
The PMDGP is an integral part of the Punjab Government Efficiency 
Improvement Program Cluster approved by ADB in December 2007.  
Program  The  PMDGP  marks  a  major  priority  shift  by  the  Punjab  Health 
Description  Department from quantity to quality of health care, from fragmented to 
consolidated health service, and from tertiary to primary and secondary 
health care. The impact of the PMDGP is the attainment of MDGs 
relating  to  the  reduction  of  the  infant  mortality  rate  and  maternal 
mortality  ratio  in  Punjab  Province.  The  Program’s  outcome  will  be 
improved access, quality, and equity of health services. The Program 
will  assist  the  GoPb  in  undertaking  health  sector  reforms  in  the 
following areas.  
(i)  Improving  the  Availability  and  Quality  of  Primary  and 
Secondary Health Services. PMDGP will help GoPb ensure 
the  implementation  of  certain  minimum  service  delivery 
standards (MSDS) for primary and secondary health services, 
through  incorporation  of  the  MSDS  in  provincial  and  district 
health sector plans, and by increasing the quality and quantity of 
human resources in the health sector.  
(ii)  Strengthening  Management  of  Health  Service  Delivery. 
PMDGP will help the GoPb improve the daily management of 
health service delivery by reducing delays in the procurement of 
essential  drugs,  institutionalizing  the  contracting  of  health 
services  to  nongovernment  organizations,  and  improving  the 
existing performance monitoring and evaluation systems.  
 
(iii)  Establishing  a  Sustainable  Pro-Poor  Health  Financing 
System. PMDGP will assist the GoPb in substantially increasing 
the  health  care  budget  and  improving  planning  and 
management of the budget, introducing a targeted program for 
reducing out-of-pocket health expenditure among the poor, and 
developing  a  sustainable  health  care  financing  and  provider 
payment system.

iii
Financing Plan  Full  implementation  of  the  MSDS  is  projected  to  cost  GoPb 
PRs34 billion ($425 million) over 2008-2011. The first phase of MSDS 
implementation, with focus on maternal, neonatal, and child health, will 
cost about PRs7 billion ($88 million) apart from expenditure for capacity 
building and enhancement of information systems. Overall, health and 
safety-net related public expenditures are estimated at $735 million for 
FY2009. For subprogram 1, given the significant pro-poor impact of the 
proposed measures, ADB will provide a loan of $100 million equivalent 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources. For subsequent programs, $200 
million–$300  million  in  total  is  envisaged,  depending  on  reform 
progress, expenditure requirements and the availability of resources. 
   
  The loan from ADB’s Special Funds resources will have an interest rate 
of  1%  per  annum  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5%  per  annum 
thereafter, a term of 24 years, including a grace period of 8 years, and 
such other terms and conditions as set forth in the loan agreement. The 
Borrower will be the Islamic Republic of Pakistan. The Government of 
Pakistan will relend the local currency generated from the proceeds of 
the loan to GoPb. The terms and conditions will be the same as those 
extended by ADB to the Borrower.  
Counterpart Funds  The local currency counterpart funds generated from the loan will be 
used to increase the GoPb’s health sector budget, and transferred to 
the district governments, earmarked for implementing MSDS.  
 
Program Period and  The implementation period for PMDGP subprogram 1 is from January 
Tranche Release  to  October  2008.  The  indicative  implementation  period  for 
subprogram 2 is November 2008–November 2009; for subprogram 3, it 
is January–December 2010. The loans supporting the subprograms of 
the PMDGP will be disbursed in a single tranche subject to satisfactory 
completion  of  all  policy  actions  applicable  for  the  respective 
subprogram,  and  effectiveness  of  the  respective  subprogram.  Upon 
completion  of  all  subprograms,  the  PMDGP  is  expected  to  be 
completed by 30 June 2011.  
   
Executing Agency   The Health Department of GoPb will be the Executing Agency.  
   
Implementation  The program management unit for the Health Sector Reform Program 
Arrangements  will  be  responsible  for  daily  coordination  and  management  of  the 
PMDGP. The existing program steering committee for the health sector 
reform  program—chaired  by  chairman  of  the  Planning  and 
Development Board, comprising the secretary of health, secretary of 
finance, secretary of local government and community development, 
and health care providers as members—will be the program steering 
committee for the PMDGP and oversee policy decisions. The program 
steering committee will meet at least once every 6 months. A working 
group will be constituted for developing pro-poor health care financing 
and provider payment.  
Procurement and  The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange 
Disbursement  costs (excluding local duties and taxes) of items produced and procured 
in ADB member countries, excluding the items specified in a negative

iv     
list  of  ineligible  items  (and  imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and 
multilateral  sources).  The  proceeds  of  the  program  loan  will  be 
disbursed  to  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Pakistan  as  the  Borrower.  No 
supporting import documentation will be required if, during each year 
that  the  loan  proceeds  are  expected  to  be  disbursed,  the  value  of 
Pakistan’s  total  imports  minus  imports  from  nonmember  countries, 
ineligible imports, and imports financed under other official development 
assistance is equal to or greater than the amount of the loan expected 
to  be  disbursed  during  that  year.  The  Government  of  Pakistan  will 
certify its compliance with this formula with each withdrawal request. 
Otherwise,  import  documentation  under  existing  procedures  will  be 
required. Disbursements will be made under the simplified procedures 
for program loans.  
   
Program Benefits  Improved Access and Quality of Primary and Secondary Health 
and Impacts  Care  Services.  By  helping  Punjab  attain  the  health  MDGs,  the 
proposed Program could potentially save up to 11,000 women’s lives 
and 235,000 lives of infants by 2015 compared to the scenario without 
program  support.  This  would  be  contingent,  however,  on  additional 
investments being made by the GoPb. By helping district governments 
to  endorse  and  implement  MSDS,  the  Program  will  ensure  that 
standards are followed across the province.  
 
Poverty  Reduction.  Poor  people  have  the  worst  health  outcomes. 
They are pushed further into poverty because of ill health—resulting in 
lower productivity or loss of daily wages, and burden of health care 
expenditure. Although public health care is in principle free, patients 
often have to pay a substantial amount because of missing drugs and 
supplies at public health facilities. The proposed Program will reduce 
the health care burden and the risks of falling seriously ill through timely 
health interventions, by making quality care available and affordable at 
public  facilities  through  a  targeted  program,  and  through  the 
development of an equitable health financing system.  
 
Economic Impact. Improved public financial management in the health 
sector and better strategic planning skills in the Health Department will 
contribute to increased value for money of public spending. Provision of 
conditional grants to district governments for MDG-related interventions 
will ease the district governments’ resource limitation while ensuring 
that  social  sectors  are  protected  from  expenditure  cuts.  Increased 
access to and quality of public health services will also have a direct 
poverty reducing impact by reducing the burden of health expenditures 
on the poor.  
 
Sustainable  and  Efficient  Health  Care  Financing  System.  The 
Program will increase and improve the efficiency of the public stream of 
health care financing while supporting development of alternative health 
care  financing  systems  that  may  pool  different  financial  resources. 
Strengthened  internal  controls  and  increased  transparency  in  the 
allocation  of  resources  will  ensure  that  public  funds  are  spent  in 
accordance to needs and that resource leakage is minimized.

v
 
Institutional Impact. Establishment of the strategy and policy unit and 
financial management cell within the Health Department will ensure that 
policies  and  strategies  are  properly  defined,  corresponding  actions 
planned,  and  resources  allocated  accordingly;  and  that  the  budget 
preparation and execution process is owned at the managerial level. 
Revitalization of the internal audit wing and of the departmental account 
committees in the Health Department, and appointing internal auditors 
at district governments, will increase accountability for the use of public 
funds.  
  
Risks  Revisions to the Decentralization Framework. The future of the local 
government system under the present political setup may be at risk. 
While a drastic reversal of the devolved setup is unlikely, changes in 
the  current  attribution  of  power  and  authority  across  levels  of 
government may occur. However, the health sector is likely to remain 
devolved  given  the  ground  level  implementation  requirements. 
Regardless, the flexibility built into the cluster approach is suitable for 
changing the implementation arrangements.  
 
Governance Risks. As in any complex environment with capacity and 
resource constraints, there are governance risks in the areas of public 
financial management, expenditure planning and control, procurement, 
and anticorruption. As a program loan, the PMDGP deliberately and 
explicitly puts governance and public expenditure management issues 
at the center of the reform effort. Reforms proposed under the PMDGP 
will positively affect the current institutional setup in the health sector 
and address these governance risks. The change in public financial 
management practices and the emphasis on results-based allocation of 
resources is likely to encounter resistance from middle management 
officials who have vested interests in perpetuating the current situation. 
The  strong  commitment  to  reform  at  the  highest  political  and 
bureaucratic level within the Health Department will help mitigate this 
risk.  In  addition,  internal  and  external  performance  monitoring  and 
evaluation, and publicizing the performance are expected to change the 
situation gradually. The PMDGP has built-in third party assessments, 
including a citizen satisfaction survey, as policy conditions.  
 
Implementation  Risks.  The  proposed  Program  is  building  on  the 
achievements of the Punjab Devolved Social Services Program and the 
Public  Resource  Management  Program,  but  still  requires  technical 
assistance (TA) support for capacity building of district governments 
and  the  Office  of  the  Director  General,  Health  Services;  and  for 
designing  health  care  financing.  Based  on  past  implementation 
problems encountered in TA loans in Pakistan, a deliberate decision 
was taken against a TA loan for the PMDGP. The Health Department is 
coordinating  with  the  PDSSP  program  management  unit  to  utilize 
resources from an ongoing $20 million TA grant attached to the Punjab 
Devolved Social Services Program (financed by the Department for 
International Development of the United Kingdom) to mitigate the risk.

vi     
External  and  Macroeconomic  Risks.  The  recent  upsurge  in 
international  commodity  prices  is  having  an  adverse  impact  on 
Pakistan’s macroeconomic  indicators.  The  global  financial  turmoil  is 
also likely to affect the economy. While recurrent and development 
expenditures  need  to  be  managed  carefully,  essential  pro-poor 
investments in health and education are likely to be preserved at the 
federal  and  provincial  levels.  Finally,  the  political  commitment  to 
investments in social sectors will protect pro-poor investments from 
budget cuts.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
program cluster to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for the Punjab Millennium Development 
Goals  Program  (PMDGP)  comprising  three  subprograms,  and  (ii)  a  proposed  loan  for 
subprogram 1 of the PMDGP.1 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
2.  Fiscal year (FY) 2008 has witnessed a reversal of the sustained growth path that has 
characterized the Pakistan economy since early 2000s. For the first time since FY2003, the 
economy has posted a real gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate below 6%, caused by 
both domestic and international developments. During FY2008, domestic supply shocks and 
rising international food and fuel prices have pushed inflation above 25%. After 2 years of 
modest increase, the fiscal deficit–GDP ratio rose to 7.4% in FY2008, breaching the 4% of GDP 
threshold set by the Fiscal Responsibility Act, 2005. Higher global food and fuel prices have 
affected the budget through higher subsidies for oil, wheat, electricity, and fertilizers. During 
FY2008, government borrowing from the central bank has almost doubled, as it has been a 
main source of deficit financing2 in the presence of a deteriorating external account. The current 
account deficit has deteriorated (about 8% against a target 5%) because of higher imports, 
driven by higher prices and strong aggregate demand, and lower exports, especially in the 
textile sector. The capital account surplus has also deteriorated because of a decline in foreign 
direct investments and lower portfolio investments. On the other hand, the growth in remittances 
(17.4%) has not been sufficient to offset the decline in other components of the capital account. 
The progressive depletion of foreign exchange reserves has led to a sharp depreciation (22%) 
of the Pakistan rupee against the US dollar since July 2007. In order to restore stability, the 
Government  of  Pakistan  has  signed  a  Letter  of  Intent  on  20  November  2008  seeking  a 
$7.6 billion stand-by arrangement from the International Monetary Fund, as part of which broad-
ranging macroeconomic reforms have been agreed upon. 
 
3.  Punjab contributes more than 50% of the Pakistan’s GDP and is home to 56% of its total 
population. Punjab’s GDP growth rate for FY2007 was estimated at 7.8%. The slowdown of the 
national economy is likely to impact Punjab’s economy as well. Although reliable data on GDP 
growth projections are not available, revised budget figures for FY2008 and budget estimates 
for FY2009 provide some insights as to the effects of the economic slowdown on the provincial 
economy.  These  point  to  a  widening  budget  deficit  mostly  caused  by  shrinking  revenue 
receipts.3 General revenue receipts have decreased by 11% because of lower tax (–18%) and 
non-tax (–30%) revenues and lower federal transfers (–3%) and grants (–34%) during FY2008. 
Total expenditures have been lower than budgeted (–8%) mainly because of lower development 
spending (–13%). 
 
4.  The provincial budget for FY2009 contains a subsidy package of PRs13 billion in the 
form  of  cash  transfers  to  the  poorest  to  compensate  for  higher  food  prices  and  maintain 
affordability of health services. For FY2009, Punjab’s share of the national financial commission 
award will be 25% higher than in FY2008 because of the federal government’s decision to 
increase the general sales tax on consumer goods and services from 15% to 16%, which may 
help meet the additional expenditures somewhat. Provincial tax revenues will increase by 8%,

5.  Against this backdrop of fiscal constraints, GoPb has been able to preserve health 
sector spending from drastic cuts. Although starting from a low base, per capita health spending 
by the public sector has been increasing in recent years—$4.4 in FY2007; $5.77 in FY2008 
(revised estimates); and $6.38 in FY2009 (budget estimates). Yet, this is far less than the 
resource allocation in comparable South Asian countries.5  
 
6.  GoPb has sought support from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to bolster its efforts 
to  increase  the  quality  of  and  access  to  key  social  services,  especially  by  improving 
management of service delivery and public resources. GoPb has been undertaking education 
sector reforms for the last several years with the World Bank’s program support, and has seen 
education Millennium Development Goal (MDG) indicators improve. On the other hand, health 
MDGs have shown very little improvement. In line with the thrust of ADB’s recently approved 
long-term strategic framework (Strategy 2020),6 the PMDGP will support health sector reforms 
with the objective of promoting inclusive growth, by improving access—particularly of the poor—
to  quality  health  care.  As  a  programmatic  operation,  the  PMDGP  will  not  directly  finance 
construction  of  health  facilities,  and  it  will  approach  health  sector  and  public  financial 
management reforms with the goal of improving the overall efficiency of the public sector, in line 
with  the  thrust  of  Strategy  2020.  ADB  has  been  working  with  GoPb  through  the  Punjab 
Devolved Social Services Program (PDSSP)7 for the past 3 years. It has also provided support 
for broad-based public sector resource management reforms through the Punjab Resource 
Management  Program  (PRMP) 8  from  2003–2007,  and  through  the  Punjab  Government 
Efficiency Improvement Program (PGEIP)9 approved in December 2007. At the request of GoPb, 
the conceptual framework for the proposed PMDGP was included as part of the PGEIP.  
 
III.  THE SECTOR 
A.  Sector Description and Performance 
7.  At the national level, Pakistan recognizes the need to improve health outcomes as an 
important part of the Government’s poverty alleviation plan. Pakistan’s National Health Policy 
200110 prioritizes  primary  and  secondary  health  care,  and  emphasizes  the  need  for  good 
governance as the basis of health sector reform. However, the national policy has not been 
implemented effectively because of resource and capacity constraints, and the absence of a 
concrete action plan with measurable outputs. As a result, Pakistan compares poorly on infant 
and maternal mortality indicators among the South Asian countries (Table 1). Pakistan also lags 
behind comparable countries with respect to public as well as private expenditures on health

11.  Timely use of quality primary and secondary health care by the poor, especially women 
and children in rural areas, is the key to attaining the MDGs relating to the IMR and MMR. The 
Punjab Local Government Ordinance (PLGO) has made the district governments responsible 
for primary and secondary health services, which are the key to attaining MDGs, whereas the 
provincial Health Department has retained responsibility for policy setting for the entire sector; 
performance monitoring; and the provision of tertiary care services, medical education, and 
research and development. Punjab’s primary health service system consists of 293 rural health 
centers (RHCs), 2,456 basic health units (BHUs), and 188 maternal and child health centers. 
For secondary health services, there are 35 district headquarter hospitals (DHQs) and 77 tehsil 
headquarter hospitals (THQs). Punjab has over 140,000 health department employees spread 
across its 35 districts.  
12.  Realizing that health MDGs would not be attained without wide-ranging health sector 
reforms, GoPb has developed a health sector reform framework as part of the ADB-supported 
PRMP. It has also designed a Health Sector Reform Program (HSRP), which has been under 
implementation with GoPb’s own financing since 2006.13 In parallel, GoPb has taken measures 
to strengthen district level social service delivery systems through the PDSSP. GoPb has also 
adopted minimum service delivery standards (MSDS) for health services through PDSSP.  
B.  Issues and Opportunities 
13.  In Punjab, the health system consists of two parallel streams. The budget-based public 
health system provides health care to any user of a public facility, with negligible official user 
charges. The private health care system is largely unregulated and charges fees for services. 
Qualified private providers mainly cater to urban populations who can afford the fees. Public 
sector spending accounts for less than 20% of total expenditures, with privately provided and 
procured health care dominating the sector. Yet, for the rural poor, public health facilities are 
often the only choice for receiving qualified and affordable medical care.  
14.  Despite the massive network of public primary and secondary health facilities, coverage 
of basic health services remains low (Appendix 4). The reasons for low coverage of basic health 
services include limited availability and low quality of services, and suboptimal health-seeking 
behavior. Public primary health care has been largely underutilized mainly because of the 
absence of doctors, unavailability of drugs, and unreliable and poor quality of services. The 
biggest obstacle for improving quality is the absence of doctors and paramedics, and the poor 
quality  of  their  training.  The  day-to-day  management  of health  services  has  suffered  from 
inadequate  capacity,  challenges  in  recruiting  and  posting  motivated  doctors  and  other 
professionals in rural and remote areas, rigid administrative procedures, inefficient and lengthy 
procurement processes for drugs and medical supplies, and lack of performance monitoring to

15.  Public health service in Pakistan is financed and managed by governments at three 
different levels—federal, provincial, and district. The 2001 PLGO devolved responsibility for 
primary and secondary health service delivery to district governments. However, this devolution 
was not supported by sufficient structural changes and capacity building efforts for the Health 
Department, especially for the Office of Director General, Health Services (ODGHS), and for 
district  governments.  District  governments  remain  dependent  on  provincial  fiscal  transfers. 
Although budget planning and execution is transferred to district governments, there is limited 
planning  and  management  capacity  at  district  health  departments.  The  approval  of  health 
workers’ posts in primary and secondary health care facilities largely remain with the Health 
Department, not with district governments, while the recruitment of lower level posts has been 
shifted to district governments’ responsibility. No mechanism has been developed yet to monitor 
the performance of the district health departments. Federally-financed health programs have 
their own implementation and reporting mechanisms, and their coordination and information-
sharing with district health departments is often limited.  
16.  Figure 1 illustrates the key challenges facing the attainment of the two critical health 
MDGs in Punjab. In summary, the delivery of maternal, neonatal, and child health (MNCH) 
service in Punjab suffers from three main problems: 
(i)  low quality and uneven adherence to service delivery norms, 
(ii)  poor management of health service delivery, and 
(iii)  inadequate financing and weak fiduciary systems. 
1.  Need for Implementing Service Delivery Standards 
17.  The demand for, and spending on, private health care is higher because the public 
perceive the quality of private health care to be better than that at public health facilities. Low 
quality, lack of standardized provision of health services within and across health facilities, lack 
of adequate human resources, and lack of drugs and medical supplies have been the main 
impediments resulting in the low utilization of BHUs and RHCs. The public either chooses to use 
unqualified health care providers or home treatment, or go to hospitals even for minor illnesses. 
This  has  resulted  in  delays  in  seeking  appropriate  health  care  when  needed  as  well  as 
overcrowded hospitals. 
18.  Both the federal and provincial governments are allowed to set health sector policies. 
Although the GoPb does not have a health sector policy specific to Punjab, the National Health 
Policy gives a reasonable vision, focusing on (i) poverty alleviation, (ii) primary and secondary 
health care, and (iii) good governance. However, it does not specify the steps and outputs 
required for realizing the vision or MDGs. Without specifying what services are provided at 
which level of health care by whom, and the minimum acceptable quality for different types of 
services to achieve the goals, it has been impossible to translate the policy and the MDG 
commitment of GoPb into investments and action plans.

19.  The MSDS notified in Punjab in December 2007 have filled this crucial gap. They were 
developed  through  consultations  involving  provincial  and  district  health  officials  and  public 
health specialists, based on reviews of service delivery standards in other South Asian countries 
(Bangladesh, India, and Sri Lanka); the international evidence-based standards set by the 
World Health Organization for developing countries; and existing services in Punjab. The MSDS 
define the minimum package of services that the public is entitled to, a set of performance 
indicators and minimum acceptable levels of performance by service providers at each level of 
health care, and the required physical and human resource requirements. To facilitate the 
implementation  of  MSDS,  GoPb  has  also  developed  comprehensive  referral  guidelines, 
standard operating procedures (SOPs), and standard medical protocols (SMPs). MSDS, SOPs, 
and SMPs together have well-defined accountability parameters at each level of health care, for

different health professionals, and benchmarks against which performance of the health system 
as a whole and that of each worker will be monitored and evaluated.  
20.  Implementation of the MSDS, SOPs, SMPs, and the referral system will help attain the 
MDGs  and  lead  to  an  overall  improvement  in  public  health  through  better  primary  and 
secondary health care. These standards and protocols need to be updated periodically based 
on emerging requirements. In parallel, building capacity for evidence-based medicine will be a 
medium-term requirement.  
21.  The lack of well-trained human resources is the biggest constraint in implementing 
MSDS. To implement the MNCH-related MSDS successfully, it is critical to have adequate and 
well-qualified and skilled women medical officers (WMOs), midwives, nurses, female health 
visitors, and paramedics. Currently, about 22% of the approved posts for various health workers 
at BHUs and RHCs in Punjab are vacant. Among the medical staff, the highest (32%) proportion 
of vacant posts is for the WMO. Similarly, 37% of the approved posts for nurses at BHUs and 
RHCs are currently vacant. At DHQs, almost one third of the approved posts of gynecologists 
and anesthetists are vacant. The situation is even worse at THQs, where 48% of the approved 
posts of gynecologists and 59% of anesthetists’ posts are vacant. 14 
 
22.  To implement MNCH-related MSDS effectively, about 14,000 new posts need to be 
approved and filled. They include about 660 specialists (primarily gynecologists, obstetricians, 
anesthetists,  and  pediatricians);  about  1,550  medical  officers  (including  WMOs);  about 
5,000 nurses; 3,000 each of lady health visitors and midwives; and 1,000 paramedics. The 
shortage is especially pronounced among paramedics and nurses. Against this requirement, 
Punjab produces about 1,400–1,600 nurses and 350 lady health visitors per year. In addition, 
39,000  nurses  have  been  registered  until  2006.  Therefore,  once  posts  are  approved,  a 
substantial part of them are expected to be filled in the next 2 years. For some posts, however, 
additional measures may be necessary for attracting health workers to the posts. For example, 
Punjab produces a large number of doctors—including female doctors—in relation to nurses, 
but the availability of WMOs (particularly in rural areas) is a challenge as many female doctors 
leave the profession or opt to practice in urban areas. GoPb has introduced incentives for 
doctors posted at BHUs. As a result, their vacancies at BHUs have significantly reduced for the 
last 2 years.  
 
23.  Apart from the quantitative challenge, there are serious quality concerns in the health 
profession. Some of the medical training institutions in Punjab do not appear to apply any 
stringent quality standards. In addition, there is no continuous education system to enable 
doctors to update their knowledge and skills regularly. Further, the quality of paramedics is not 
up to required standards. For instance, the entrance requirement for dispensers is only 10 years 
of schooling. Since 1947, only about 35,000 dispensers have been qualified out of 1.2 million 
who appeared for the exam after a year of training. The quality of training offered is very low 
mainly because of lack of qualified trainers. Consequently, the quality of the paramedics is low 
and they are ill-prepared to offer quality care.   
  
24.  The HSRP has made substantial headway in closing gaps in physical infrastructure and 
staff requirements. Vacant positions at RHCs and BHUs are being filled through monetary 
incentives for doctors. Absenteeism is actively checked. Correspondingly, the utilization rates of 
RHCs  and  BHUs  are  increasing,  albeit  slowly.  The  federal  MNCH  program  also  plans  to 
upgrade the maternal wards and delivery rooms of DHQs, THQs, and RHCs. The federal

2.  Need for Improved Management of Health Service Delivery 
25.  Management and Performance Monitoring. One of the lessons from the PDSSP is 
that district governments require substantial technical assistance (TA) to develop and manage a 
rational and strategic action plan. ODGHS, which was responsible for delivering district health 
services before the 2001 devolution, is now responsible for providing TA to district governments 
and monitoring performance of health services in districts. The structure and capacity of the 
office, however, has not been adjusted to its new responsibilities; consequently, there is a 
serious vacuum of monitoring and supervision. The office still has 10 senior directors and 
350 supporting staff, and in some cases continues to work on services that are supposed to 
have been devolved. On the other hand, the district health departments are left to assume 
responsibilities  for  primary  and  secondary  health  service  delivery,  without  the  Health 
Department’s technical support.  
 
26.  Monitoring and evaluation (M&E) cannot be effective in the absence of a comprehensive 
information  system.  There  is  no  consolidated  source  in  place  that  provides  reliable  and 
comprehensive health information on time to those managing health services. At the provincial 
level,  the  HSRP  has  its  own  effective  mechanism  of  collecting  information  through  M&E 
assistants whereas ODGHS collects routine information from health facilities through executive 
district  officers  (EDOs),  Health.  Federal  or  provincial  vertical  programs  and  donor-funded 
projects have their own mechanisms to collect information through their respective district and 
subdistrict coordinators. In addition, a number of studies and community surveys are being 
undertaken by  various stakeholders. However, the collected information is hardly used for 
improving health services, particularly at the local level.  
 
27.  Recently  the  Health  Department  has  pilot  tested  a  comprehensive  district  health 
information system (DHIS), which can generate information on indicators related to service 
delivery, human resources, financial management, logistics, capital assets, and regulations. 
DHIS is gradually becoming operational in the pilot districts. Districts’ capacity is the major 
constraint in rapid expansion. The posts for a director at ODGHS for DHIS have only recently 
been filled and district DHIS related officers’ posts have not yet been filled. DHIS will be an 
important instrument for the Health Department to monitor district health service performance 
and adjust its strategies.  
28.  Drug Procurement. There is a shortage of drugs across primary and secondary health 
facilities. While inadequate budget allocation is one key reason, cumbersome drug procurement 
procedures seem to be another major cause. Efficient procurement of drugs is an essential part 
of the drug management cycle, and plays a key role in ensuring cost-effective and timely 
availability of quality drugs and medicines. Drug procurement absorbs a substantial portion of 
the health budget of each facility. For these reasons, good procurement systems are vital—not 
just for health service delivery but also for ensuring efficient use of public funds.  
29.  In Punjab, essential drugs are supposed to be provided free at any public facility. After 
the 2001 devolution, each district government has become responsible for purchasing the drugs 
and medicines in the essential drug list defined at the federal level. After contracts are awarded,

9
the supplier delivers the drugs to each facility and a sample of each batch is submitted to the 
drug test laboratory for testing before payment to the supplier can be authorized. 
 
30.  The decentralized procedure, however, showed its limitation through large differences in 
procurement prices across district governments. Therefore, since FY2008, GoPb has introduced 
a partial centralization of the procurement process under which the Health Department, through 
its procurement cell, would be responsible for determining the price range on behalf of all district 
governments. However, the procurement cycle and awarding of contracts are protracted. The 
process only starts on 31 August of each fiscal year, as prescribed by the purchase manual, 
and it is expected to be completed by mid-October. As a result, district governments could start 
procuring  the  needed  supplies  of  drugs  and  medicines  only  around  October,  sometimes 
extending to January or February, leaving district governments to complete drug procurement 
within the remaining few months of the fiscal year. Similarly, the drug test laboratory is flooded 
with requests for drug testing just for these few months. This mismatch between the financial 
cycle of the district governments and their procurement process increases the risk of drug 
shortages in case of delays in the award of the procurement contract.  
31.  There is a need to define a uniform and accepted procedure for procurement, streamline 
the current process and its timing, and ensure that the compiled listings of drugs and supplies 
by each facility are updated and made consistent with both the facility needs and the essential 
drug list.  
32.  Alternative  Service  Delivery  Models.  Punjab  has  tried  two  models  of  contracting 
health service delivery, one with the Punjab Rural Support Program (PRSP) and the other with 
the National Commission for Human Development (NCHD). The PRSP has covered BHUs in 
12 districts to date, while NCHD has covered one district and may be expanded to other districts. 
The PRSP has managed BHUs on behalf of the district governments. It has been given funds 
under its contract with the districts to operate the BHUs. It also has the authority to hire and fire 
BHU health workers. NCHD provides additional services specified in the contract with the 
district governments, including financial resources to top up the regular primary health care 
budget. 
33.  Both  the  PRSP  and  NCHD  are  classified  as  government-owned  nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs), associated with the federal government. They operate as independent 
entities to execute the health service management contracts. As there are only two at present, 
and since the other NGOs are smaller and lack scale economies, NCHD and the PRSP have 
been entrusted with most of the BHUs that are contracted out. As a result, their selection as 
contractors is not competitive. Some EDOs, Health see their presence as interference. There is 
an opinion that district governments could manage the district health system more efficiently, if 
the same administrative power given to these NGOs is given to EDOs. As a result of these 
concerns, GoPb is planning to improve and institutionalize contracting models in district health 
service  delivery,  incorporating  lessons  from  a  systematic  third-party  evaluation  of  the  two 
models.  
 
34.   With various vertical programs financed by the federal and provincial governments, and 
the NGO- and donor-financed programs for MNCH services, service delivery in districts risks 
fragmentation, duplication, and inefficiency in resource use. Although most of the programs at 
least  keep  EDOs,  Health  informed,  they  have  separate  management  and  reporting 
arrangements.  GoPb  has  been  long  aware  of  the  problems,  and  is  keen  on  functionally 
integrating primary health services at BHU level. ODGHS has been tasked to conceptualize and 
oversee the integration process.

3.  Need for Greater and Rationally Allocated Financial Resources and 
Effective Resource Management 
35.  Under-Financing  at  the  National  Level.  Public  health  care  is  financed  through 
budgetary allocations from three different levels of government: federal, provincial, and district. 
Pakistan’s  public  health  care  has  been  persistently  underfinanced.  Its  total  health  care 
expenditure in 2004 was only 2.2% of GDP, more than 80% of which was private expenditure. 
Per capita government expenditure on health was only $9.4, against a benchmark of about $30 
recommended by the World Health Organization for developing countries. It also compares 
unfavorably with neighboring countries such as Sri Lanka ($74.1), Nepal ($18.6), Bangladesh 
($18.1), and India ($15.8).  
36.  The increase in district governments’ spending responsibilities has not been matched by 
concurrent revenue autonomy necessary to fulfill this new role. District governments depend on 
the provincial fiscal transfers for a large part of their revenues through Provincial Finance 
Commission (PFC) awards. District governments typically spend less than $2 per capita on 
health  care,  severely  under-financing  primary  and  secondary  health  care.  This  has  led  to 
shortage of drugs and medical supplies across health facilities. For FY2003–FY2007, total 
health sector expenditure accounted for 6%–13% of district governments’ total regular budget. 
The health sector’s share in district governments’ recurrent budget ranges from 7%–19%, and 
0%–7% in the development budget depending on the district. Salaries account for about 60% of 
total health expenditures. The HSRP and the tied grants received under the ADB-supported 
PDSSP are sometimes the sole sources of funding for health sector development schemes in 
some districts. Under the PDSSP, conditional grants are being provided to district governments 
and the tehsil municipal administration to achieve progress toward MDGs related to poverty, 
gender, education, health, and water supply and sanitation. The grants are transferred as part of 
the PFC award. Seventy percent of the grant is transferred based on population and 30% based 
on  the  development  deprivation  index  calculated  based  on  the  Multiple  Indicators  Cluster 
Survey  data.  A  memorandum  of  understanding  (MOU)  between  GoPb  and  each  local 
government sets the rules and conditions of the grants. The MOU defines the specific eligibility 
criteria and access criteria each local government has to meet to receive the grants. It also 
establishes criteria for the use of funds, including the request that funds be kept in a civil 
account and that such account and related financial statements be audited annually by the 
District Audit Office of the Auditor General of Pakistan.  
 
37.  Under-Financing in Punjab. GoPb has substantially increased the budget allocation for 
health in recent years. Still, in FY2007, GoPb’s total health care spending was PRs23.5 billion, 
or $4.4 per capita, which is less than half of the national per capita spending. Overall, total 
health public spending, including spending at district level, has accounted for only 7%–8% of 
total  spending,  and  since  FY2005  the  majority  of  funds  is  being  allocated  to  recurrent 
expenditures. 
38.  Primary and secondary health care has proven to be more pro-poor than tertiary health 
care. Yet, allocation of GoPb’s health budget in the past used to be heavily tilted toward tertiary 
health care. With the introduction of the HSRP, however, 45% of the Health Department’s 
annual  development  program  was  allocated  to  primary  and  secondary  health  services  in 
FY2008. Reforms in this direction need to be sustained through the PMDGP.   
39.  Inadequate Budget Planning and Execution. Any budget increases have to be based 
on sound rationale and priorities set out by the prevailing health policy. Now that GoPb has 
developed and committed itself to attaining MSDS, which define the necessary inputs (physical

11
investment  and human resource needs) for primary and  secondary health services, GoPb 
should be able to prepare medium-term budget for these levels. However, a series of structural 
constraints prevent rational budget formulation and execution. The Medium-Term Development 
Framework shows little consistency in the projections from one year to the next and there is 
ample  variation  in  allocations  to  major  programs  in  the  health  sector  annual  development 
program. This points to poor planning of the financing needs and low predictability of financial 
allocations. 
 
40.  The planning and budget preparation processes, both at the provincial and district levels, 
share common limitations. The recurrent and the development budget process are two separate 
exercises,  with  insufficient  consideration  of  the  links  between  the  two.  The  incremental 
approach  to  budget  preparation  perpetuates  inefficiencies  and  imbalances  in  inputs  and 
resource allocation decisions. Since budget preparation remains at the lower levels of the 
department or district officers, there is a risk that the sight of goals and objectives for the 
department  or  district  governments  can  be  lost  with  incremental  budgeting.  Performance 
measurement,  both  physical  and  financial,  is  hampered  by  the  lack  of  an  integrated  and 
informed budget statement about recurrent and development activities, and by the split between 
the various development initiatives. The district governments’ allocation of resources among 
competing demands is often driven by political choices. 
 
41.  Weak  Financial  Reporting.  The  state  government’s  financial  reporting  does  not 
conform to best practices. Budget execution and expenditure statements do not allow drawing 
reliable, homogenous, and reconciled information at any level. Severe weaknesses also exist at 
the district governments. The EDO, Health does not receive regular financial statements on 
budget utilization from the health facilities under its jurisdiction. As a result, the EDO does not 
have a holistic picture of the use of resources in his district, and cannot measure performance 
against planned targets. Therefore, in spite of being the officer in charge of health service 
delivery across the district, the EDO is unable to manage programs effectively and hold staff 
and facilities responsible for delivery of services. Weak financial reporting undermines resource 
allocation decisions at the time budget estimates are prepared or revised, and prevents rational 
scrutiny of resources utilized in service delivery. 
 
42.  At the provincial level, there is a similar absence of consolidated financial reporting 
showing  budget  execution  for  the  various  provincial  level  programs  and  sections  in  the 
secretariat as well as for the district governments. The reliance on prior control for each item of 
expenditure does not ensure proper budgetary control as this would involve monitoring the 
performance of a unit or entity, including financial performance, and taking corrective action 
where  necessary.  Dual  budgeting  also  restricts  the  scope  for  comprehensive  analysis  of 
government operations and evaluation of their performance. Like the EDO, Health, the secretary 
of health—as the principal accounting officer for the Health Department—has limited access to 
consolidated financial information to enable proper scrutiny of the performance of subordinate 
officers, facilities, or spending units, let alone having an overview of overall resource allocation 
and financial performance in the public health sector. 
 
43.  Weak Fiduciary Environment. An organization’s internal control system is defined as 
the whole network of systems established to provide reasonable assurance that objectives will 
be achieved in an efficient and economic manner; and that policies, procedures, laws, and 
regulations are complied with. A well-structured and executed internal control system ensures 
the integrity and reliability of information, accounts, and data; and provides assurance that the 
institutions’ assets and interests are protected from losses. The role of internal audit, in turn, is 
based on the presence of an adequate, effective, and reliable set of internal controls. Any audit

12  
will need to begin by assessing the controls in place and indicating where the controls are failing 
or are inadequate. 
 
44.  In Punjab, the manual of financial rules and regulations, the purchase manual, and other 
documents and handbooks define the set of internal controls at provincial and district levels. 
These consist mainly of ex-ante controls on all non-salary expenditures, ultimately enforced by 
the district account officer at the district level and Accountant General’s Office at the provincial 
level. This effectively limits commitments to cash availability and approved budget allocations, 
and is effective in controlling expenditures. However, as the recent assessment15 noted, while 
the rules are widely understood, in some cases they may be excessive, cause unnecessary 
delays, and are generally not adhered to effectively. 
 
45.  Punjab’s internal audit function is not effective. Although a number of key departments 
have some form of internal audit functions, these are not focused on systems, the reporting is 
irregular, and not all recommendations are acted upon. In district governments, the appointment 
of internal audit staff by district nazims (mayors) has generally not taken place. In the Health 
Department, the internal audit function has weakened substantially and is being used in an ad 
hoc manner since devolution. Its role and direction are unclear and its reporting line is to the 
additional secretary for establishment rather than to the secretary, as it should be given that the 
latter is the principal accounts officer of the Health Department. The audit wing does not have 
any  systematic  approach  to  audit  planning,  or  formal  processes  for  reporting  to  senior 
management or an audit committee, which would approve the audit plan, review audit reports, 
and ensure follow-up actions. Within the Health Department, there is a clear misconception that 
the function of the internal audit wing is limited to supporting the department in addressing the 
audit observations raised by the external audit.  
46.  Alternative Health Financing and Provider Payment. While the increase in budget 
allocation for public health services to implement MSDS is the most urgent need and will be a 
key focus of the government policy for the next few years, GoPb is also concerned about the 
long-term  sustainability  and  equity  of  health  care  financing  and  provider  payment  system. 
Continuation of the present budget-supported public health provisions may be an option, if 
adjusted to emerging issues; clearly, this will be inadequate. As the GoPb successfully improves 
public health services, not only the relative poor, but also wealthier people, may start using 
public health services heavily. Then, the present model of basically universal free public health 
care may disproportionately subsidize wealthier people, without a progressive tax scheme in 
place, and lead to a distorted and highly unsustainable system. To develop an equitable and 
sustainable  health  financing  system,  an  in-depth  assessment,  especially  of  out-of-pocket 
expenditure,  is  required.  Until  a  holistic  equitable  health  financing  system  is  developed, 
immediate safety net measures for reducing the poor’s health expenditure burden are needed. 
47.  Public health care is in principle free, except ticket charges ranging from PRe1 to PRs7, 
and user charges for selected diagnostic tests. The user charge system, however, is in a state 
of confusion. Best practice dictates that the resources generated from user charges be kept at 
the facility level, or at least used for sector financing needs. However, Punjab’s system requires 
the user charges to be deposited to the provincial general account. The practice widely varies 
across the province. Some district governments deposit them in their own district accounts, 
sometimes with part of the collected user charges shared with the health staff, while most do not 
account for them properly. In either case, the user charges were not retained in the health

48.  Patients often incur additional out-of-pocket expenditures visiting public health facilities

gives funds to hospitals, which in turn support poor patients. Baitulmaal reimburses claims to 
those who have applied for assistance and are found to be eligible. Medical superintendents of 
public hospitals also have discretionary power to exempt up to 25% of the patients from user 
charges. Both Zakat and Baitulmaal are thinly spread over many categories of assistance, and 
application  procedures  are  cumbersome.  The  negative  connotation  associated  with  Zakat 
support receivers often discourages people from applying. To address these deficiencies in the 
existing programs, GoPb is reviewing different possibilities of programs targeted at the poor. 
One  of  them  is  health  cards  targeted  at  poor  pregnant women  and  children, who  will  be 
exempted from health care expenditure up to a certain ceiling.  
 
C.  ADB Strategy 
49.  ADB committed itself to supporting the attainment of MDGs in 2002. Strategy 2020 
reinforces that commitment. A key premise of Strategy 2020 is inclusive economic growth. It 
encourages  the  region  to  “promote  greater  access  to  opportunities  by  expanding  human 
capacities, especially for the disadvantaged, through investments in education, health and basic 
social protections.” In terms of the health sector, Strategy 2020 identifies strengthening of public 
expenditure management for cost-effective delivery of health programs and services as an area 
of ADB’s comparative advantage. In that regard, ADB’s 1999 health sector policy remains 
relevant.16 The policy stresses the need for ensuring access of the poor, women, and children to 
cost-effective preventive, promotive, and curative health services. ADB’s possible roles include 
helping developing member countries to strengthen their public sector management capacity, 
diversify health care financing sources, and adopt innovative approaches and technologies. In 
line with Strategy 2020, the proposed PMDGP will focus on enhancing access, particularly of 
the poor, to health services.    
 
D.  Coordination with Other Projects and Programs

improving women’s and children’s health. The MSDS were developed based on the World

challenging  environments.  When  provided  at  sufficient  scale  and  coverage,  international 
experience shows this approach can rapidly improve health outcomes. More specifically, the 
United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) pilots of some of the key MSDS in three districts of 
Punjab  have  shown  significant  improvements  in  access  and  outcomes.  The  PMDGP  thus 
provides a good illustration of complementarity and partnership—WHO and UNICEF identifying

E.  Lessons 
52.  Three generic pointers from past program and projects operations are relevant to this 
Program: (i) government ownership is crucial; (ii) programs and projects often fail because of 
their complexity compared to the capacity of the executing agencies; and (iii) policy matrices are 
frequently  long,  with  many  conditions,  but  tend  to  lack  linkages  between  conditions  and 
expected  impacts.17 The  social  action  program,  which  helped  the  Government  put  long-
neglected primary health services on its political agenda, also revealed that the performance of 
Pakistan’s public social sector strongly depended on political will, governance, and funding, 
rather than technical issues. The program’s experience also warns against multisector, multi-
provincial programs, and urges for capacity building. Specific to Pakistan, the recent country 
assistance  program  evaluation  presented  similar  lessons,  and  suggested  that  ADB’s 
implementation capacity has to be strengthened, especially by increasing human resource 
allocations in the resident mission.18 The PMDGP design reflects these lessons. First, it is a 
single-province, single-sector program. It has been built on the state government’s health sector 
reform programs, especially to address the priority actions recommended by the health working 
group  constituted  by  the  chief  minister  in  April  2008.  The  weak  planning,  budgeting,  and 
implementation capacity (especially in district governments) is a major bottleneck. To address 
this, a team of experts will be placed in the Health Department exclusively tasked to capacity 
building  for  district  governments.  The  proposed  policy  conditions  are  directly  linked  to 
implementation of the MSDS, which directly contributes to the program goals. Pakistan Resident 
Mission’s  capacity  has  been  built  up  in  public  resource  management  in  general,  which 
encompasses social service delivery.

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
54.   The impact of the PMDGP will be attainment of the MDGs of reducing the IMR and 
MMR in Punjab. The Program’s outcome will be improved access to, and quality and equity of, 
health services. The delivery of the minimum package of services stipulated in the MSDS, 
especially  in  MNCH,  is  the  core  strategy  for  attaining  the  MDGs.  Therefore,  the  Program 
focuses on reforms required for effective implementation of the MSDS. The Program will assist 
the GoPb in undertaking health sector reforms to (i) improve the availability and quality of 
primary  and  secondary  health  services;  (ii) manage  health  service  delivery  better;  and 
(iii) develop a sustainable and pro-poor health care financing system. The development policy 
letter  is  in  Appendix  6.  A  policy  matrix  for  subprogram  1  and  tentative  policy  actions  for 
subsequent subprograms is in Appendix 7.   
B.  Policy Framework and Actions 
1.  Improving the Availability and Quality of Primary and Secondary Health 
Services 
55.   Key actions in this reform area are to introduce institutional arrangements and provide 
adequate and skilled human resource inputs required for effectively delivering the minimum 
package of MNCH-related services stipulated in the MSDS. 
 
56.  Policy Objective 1-1: MSDS Introduced to Primary and Secondary Health Services. 
This policy objective aims to introduce public services standards, which should be eventually 
observed by private practitioners. The MSDS define a set of services to be available at each 
health facility, and coverage targets for each service. GoPb has decided that MSDS should be 
enforced in phases, with the first phase comprising MNCH-related standards (Appendix 8). 
During subprogram 1, all districts will have agreed to reach the minimum acceptable levels of 
MSDS by 2012, by signing MOUs with the GoPb. The MOU clearly specifies the responsibilities

MNCH-related MSDS in 2009, and a total of 15 in 2010, with others complying prior by 2012. 
57.  MSDS  implementation  guidelines  that  spell  out  technical  and  financial  resources

prepared by GoPb in consultation with district governments. ODGHS helps district governments

health workers, and communities during subprogram 2 and onward through various media.

70.  Policy Objective 2-3: Alternative Models of Health Service Delivery Examined and 
Institutionalized. Contracting of health services, or health service management, could help 
improve the effectiveness and efficiency of health service delivery, as shown in other countries.

3.  Establishing Sustainable Pro-Poor Health Financing Arrangements  
71.  Public  health  care  has  been  underfinanced  in  Punjab.  GoPb  should  substantially

and simultaneously improve the targeting of public health financing and efficiency of funds. This 
reform area addresses the need for pro-poor health care financing and improving the efficiency 
of limited resources. 
 
72.  Policy Objective 3-1: Greater Provision and More Rational Budget Allocation for 
the Health Sector, especially for Primary and Secondary Health Services. Attaining the 
MDGs  relating  to  the  IMR  and  MMR  requires  a  substantial  increase  in  public  health 
expenditures. It is equally important that the increased public resources are allocated more 
rationally to those key gaps and bottlenecks in the system. This requires effective medium-term 
strategic  planning  at  both  district  government  and  Health  Department  levels,  especially  to 
ensure that the MNCH-related MSDS are met. The capacity for such planning is very limited 
within the health sector in Punjab. Therefore, reforms in planning and budgeting are prioritized

medium-term financing plan that clearly includes the cost of ensuring compliance with the 
MSDS will be developed. This will represent the starting point for development of a more 
comprehensive medium-term expenditure framework for the health sector under subprogram 2. 
GoPb has increased actual spending in the health sector during FY2009 by 15% in accordance 
with the MTEF projection. 
74.  The low revenue autonomy of district governments suggests that any additional funding

C.  Important Features 
86.  The PMDGP has two pillars: (i) improving the quality and availability of health services, 
and (ii) improving public financial management within the health sector. ADB has extensive 
experience  in  financing  reforms  in  the  health  sector  and  public  financial  management.  By 
combining both areas in one program, the PMDGP will help GoPb achieve MDGs by making 
more effective use of available resources. For ADB’s developing member countries, attaining 
MDGs is as much a problem of technical constraints as that of managing limited resources. 
 
87.  The PMDGP marks the Health Department’s major priority shifts from quantity to quality 
of health care, from fragmented to consolidated health service, and from tertiary to primary and 
secondary health care. Building on GoPb’s health sector reform framework, which has covered 
a wide range of activities, the PMDGP will help prioritize actions around the MSDS, and give 
financial means to implement them. The PMDGP will integrate different levels of health care 
through  the  referral  system;  different  levels  of  planning  and  financing  exercises  through 
streamlined budgeting and reporting mechanisms; and institutional reforms through FMC and 
strategy and policy unit, and the Health Department and EDOs. 
88.  The PMDGP will help GoPb institutionalize contracting of health services delivery or 
management  to  other  organizations,  based  on  the  evaluation  of  pilots  in  Punjab.  This  is

23
expected to improve the efficiency of health service delivery, and make the services flexible by 
removing bureaucratic rigidities. Contracting has been successfully tried out in Cambodia and 
Bangladesh with ADB’s financial support, but has not been expanded to other countries on a 
large scale yet.   
D.  Financing Plan 
89.  The PMDGP adopts a program cluster loan approach consisting of three subprograms, 
each  supported  by  a  single-tranche  loan.  Intervals  of  about  1.0–1.5  years  are  envisaged

October 2008, subprogram 2 could be considered in December 2009, and subprogram 3 in 
December 2010.  
 
90.  The reform agenda for subprogram 2, and especially subprogram 3, will be refined 
based on progress made and emerging needs. GoPb has requested that financing support for 
subprograms 2 and 3 be about $200 million–$300 million in total, in view of the large resource

tranche will be reconfirmed during the PMDGP review and processing of each subprogram. 
 
91.  For subprogram 1, it is proposed that ADB support GoPb’s reforms under the PMDGP 
with a loan of $100 million equivalent from ADB’s Special Funds resources. The loan size for

V.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits and Impacts 
103.  Improved  Access  and  Quality  of  Primary  and  Secondary  Health  Services.  By 
helping Punjab attain the health MDGs, the proposed Program will have potentially helped the 
province save at least 11,000 women’s lives and 235,000 infants’ lives by 2015 compared to the 
scenario without program support, assuming that the two health MDGs are fully met within that 
time frame. By helping all 35 district governments endorse and implement MSDS, the Program 
will ensure that minimum acceptable levels of service delivery standards are followed across the 
entire province. The adoption of guidelines for MSDS implementation and the requirement for 
district governments to develop a time-bound and fully-costed implementation plan will help 
minimize slippages in the introduction of the minimum standards. Sufficient and capable human 
resources are an essential determinant of service quality. The proposed Program will improve 
the capacity of the Health Department and district governments to plan their human resource 
needs, and more importantly will support continued education of medical staff. Finally, progress 
toward introduction of a quality assurance mechanism for private health care providers will 
ensure a safe and uniform standard of services across the province. By ensuring primary and 
secondary health services to meet MSDS, the Program is expected to have a positive impact on 
MDG6 on HIV/AIDS. MSDS includes HIV preventive measures.  
104.  Poverty Reduction. Poor people have the worst health outcomes. They are pushed 
further into poverty because of ill health, resulting in lower productivity or loss of daily wages, 
and a burden of high health care expenditures. Although public health care is in principle free, 
patients often have to pay substantial amounts for health care because of missing drugs and 
supplies at public health facilities. The cost of care at private facilities is even more expensive. 
By making quality and affordable care available at public facilities through a targeted program, 
and the development of an equitable health financing system, the proposed Program will reduce 
the  health  care  expenditure  burden  and  the  risks  of  falling  seriously  ill  by  giving  timely 
interventions. By ensuring increased allocations to primary and secondary health care, and 
distributing the conditional grants among districts through a formula that takes into account 
poverty incidence, the Program will make public finances more pro-poor. The summary poverty 
reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 12. 
105.  Improved Management of Health Services. Timely availability of drugs and medicines 
in all health facilities is an essential aspect of health service delivery. The Program will support 
streamlining of the drug procurement process and will help the Government institutionalize 
alternative mechanisms for service delivery by building on lessons from experience.  
106.  Economic  Impact. Improved public financial management in the health sector and 
better strategic planning skills in the Health Department will contribute to increased value for 
money of public spending. Provision of conditional grants to district governments for MDG-
related interventions will ease district governments’ resource constraints while ensuring that 
essential service delivery priorities are protected from expenditure cuts. The increased access 
and quality of public health services will also have a direct poverty-reducing impact by lowering 
the burden of health expenditures on the poor.  
107.  Institutional Impact. The health sector in Punjab is in dire need of institutional reforms. 
Strengthening of the strategy and policy unit within the Health Department will ensure that 
policies and strategies are properly defined, corresponding actions planned, and resources 
allocated  accordingly.  Creation  of  the  FMC  and  related  capacity-building  interventions  will

27
ensure that the budget preparation and execution process is owned at the managerial level and 
that strategic decisions are based on realistic information through adequate reporting on the use 
of financial resources across the health sector. Revitalization of the internal audit wing and of 
the  departmental  account  committees  in  the  Health  Department,  and  appointing  internal 
auditors at district governments, will enhance the effectiveness of internal controls and increase 
accountability for the use of public funds. Simultaneously, ODGHS will be restructured and 
given capacity-building support to give technical guidance to and monitor the performance of 
health service delivery by district governments.    
B.  Risks and Mitigating Measures  
108.  Political Risks. There is strong commitment at both political and bureaucratic levels in 
Punjab to improving the living standards of the poor. To this purpose, GoPb has accorded high 
priority to investments in social sectors, particularly health and education. The FY2009 recurrent 
and development budget allocations to the health sector have substantially increased (+53% 
recurrent and +38% development). Although commitment to the broad direction of reforms is 
ensured, the future of the local government system under the new political setup may be at risk 
as  provincial  governments  across  Pakistan  are  exploring  options  to  revisit  intra-provincial 
administrative and fiscal relationships within the current local government system. While a total 
reversal of the 2001 PLGO is unlikely, changes in the current distribution of power and authority 
across levels of government may occur. The flexibility built into the single tranche operations is 
well-suited to addressing the uncertainty surrounding the local government setup, and reform 
actions may be adjusted under subprogram 2. However, if the change in the PLGO leads to 
separation of primary and secondary health services financing and administrative management, 
the negative effect of the separation (i.e., further fragmentation of the health services) would be 
very difficult to contain. ADB should dialogue closely with GoPb to avoid such fragmentation.  
109.  Governance Risks. There are several governance risks in the areas of public financial 
management, expenditure planning and control, procurement, and corruption. As a policy and 
institutional reform program, the PMDGP deliberately and explicitly puts governance and public 
expenditure management issues at the center of the reform effort. Reforms proposed under the 
PMDGP will positively affect the current institutional setup in the health sector and address 
these  governance  risks.  The  change  in  public  financial  management  practices  and  the 
emphasis on results-based allocation of resources is likely to encounter resistance from middle-
management  officials  who  have  vested  interests  in  perpetuating  the  situation.  The  strong 
commitment  to  reform  at  the  highest  political  and  bureaucratic  level  within  the  Health 
Department will help mitigate this risk. In addition, internal and external performance M&E, and 
publicizing the performance are expected to change the situation gradually. The PMDGP has 
built-in third-party assessments, including a citizen satisfaction survey, as policy conditions.  
C.  Implementation Risks  
110.  Capacity Risks. The success of the PMDGP is premised on the existence of a cadre of 
qualified and committed health professionals at all levels, and assumes that the proposed 
incentive structures ensure the retention of health professionals, particularly those posted to the 
BHUs. There are risks that the required number of health professionals may not be immediately 
available  for  the  public  sector.  To  mitigate  this  risk,  GoPb  has  introduced  monetary  and 
nonmonetary  incentives  for  doctors  posted  at  BHUs,  which  have  resulted  in  a  significant 
reduction of vacancies. In addition, the measures of the PMDGP will cascade over time, starting 
with lower levels and gradually moving up to doctors. At the lower levels, the required number of 
female health visitors, for instance, can be mobilized in a relatively short period. The Health

28  
Department will also develop a dedicated capacity-building plan, and subprograms 2 and 3 will 
provide resources for implementing the plan.   
111.  External and Macroeconomic Risks. The recent upsurge in international commodity 
prices is having an adverse impact on Pakistan’s macroeconomic indicators. While recurrent 
and development expenditures need to be managed carefully, essential pro-poor investments in 
health and education are likely to be preserved at the federal and provincial levels.  Finally, the 
political commitment to investments in social sectors will protect pro-poor investments from 
budget cuts.

SUMMARY PUNJAB HEALTH SECTOR ANALYSIS  
A.  Situation of Health Indicators and Services 
1.  The Government is a signatory to the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), and is 
fully committed to achieving them. However, progress toward achieving the MDGs in Pakistan is 
far from satisfactory. While there had been claims of poverty reduction, economic growth, and 
improvement in gross domestic product (real growth rate1 rose from 4.5% in 2003 to 6.6% in 
2007), no corresponding impact is visible on reducing maternal and child mortality. For example, 
the infant mortality rate (IMR) was 77 per 1,000 live births in 2000-2001 and 78 per 1,000 live 
births in 2006–2007. Pakistan’s IMR and maternal mortality ratio (MMR) are the highest in 
South Asia, population growth rate is the highest, and contraceptive availability the lowest. High 
population growth will increase pressure on the already weak public health service delivery 
system.  
2.  As Pakistan, including Punjab, is going through an epidemiological and demographic 
transition, it is still facing a challenge of burden of pre-transitional communicable diseases, while 
the  prevalence  of  noncommunicable  and  chronic  illnesses  is  emerging  as  an  additional 
challenge for the already compromised health service delivery system. Coupled with prevailing 
illiteracy,  poverty,  and  low  status of  women  in  society,  this  is  hampering  progress  toward 
achieving the MDGs related to maternal, neonatal and child health (MNCH). Development 
efforts are further threatened because of political instability, extremism, and violence. 
3.  Punjab health sector analysis shows that it is unlikely to achieve the MDGs unless the 
health sector is effectively reformed to make good quality MNCH services accessible to the 
masses in Punjab. To bridge urban–rural inequity in coverage, more allocation will be required 
for services in rural areas along with enhanced efficiency and institutional capacity to deliver 
good quality services. Furthermore, to achieve the MDG related to MMR (MDG5), a significant 
policy shift will be required to encourage institutional delivery to ensure that all required care can 
be offered including emergency obstetric care. 
1.  Current Status of Health MDGs 
4.  Child  Mortality  (MDG4). In Punjab, the under-five mortality rate is recorded to be 
112 per 1,000 live births (2003–2004). There is significant regional disparity, with a lower rate 
(75 per 1,000 live births) in major urban cities and a higher rate (119 per 1,000 live births) in 
rural Punjab—against the MDG target of 52 per 1,000 live births by 2015. The IMR in Punjab 
was 115 in 1996–1997 and has been reduced to 77 per 1,000 live births in 2003–2004.2 It is 
much higher in rural areas (82 per 1,000 live births) than major urban cities (55 per 1,000 live 
births). Districts located in northern Punjab close to the provincial capital report lower IMR 
compared to districts in the south. The significant urban–rural disparity shows inequity in service 
distribution and access to basic health services in Punjab.  
5.  More than half of the under-five deaths and 70% of infant deaths occur during the 
neonatal period caused by sepsis, asphyxia, preterm births, and neonatal tetanus.3 The causes

6.  The current situation suggests that achieving the MDG target for under-five mortality will

minimum service delivery standards (MSDS), are rigorously followed. If there is no significant

7.  Maternal Health (MDG5). Pakistan reports the sixth highest number of maternal deaths, 
about 15,000 a year.5 Currently, the MMR of Pakistan is estimated to be 400 per 100,000 live 
births, which shows a decline from 550 per 100,000 live births in 1990. In Punjab, the MMR is 
estimated to be 300 per 100,000 live births6 against the MDG target of 140 per 100,000 live 
births.  
8.  The main causes of maternal death include hemorrhage (53%), puerperal sepsis (16%), 
eclampsia (14%), and incomplete abortion and retained placenta (11%).7 According to the 
experts, once the postpartum hemorrhage has started the patient has only an hour or two within 
which she will require blood transfusion and obstetrical assistance to save her life. The 2006–
2007 demographic health survey revealed that lack of knowledge is the primary cause of not 
seeking medical assistance, followed by concerns about costs. Physical access to a health 
facility, including availability of transportation, is also a major problem for some pockets. The 
existing cultural norms, dominated by patriarchal characteristics and limited mobility of women, 
are sometimes a problem.  
9.  If the current MMR of 300 in Punjab is not reduced, about 10,000 mothers will die in the 
process of giving birth in 2009. Unfortunately, looking at past trends and inefficiencies in health 
care delivery systems, coupled with the poor status of women in society, it seems highly unlikely 
that this MDG will be attained unless (i) serious input is provided to reform the health sector; 
(ii) MSDS  are  strictly  implemented;  and  (iii)  effective  obstetric  emergency  care  is  made 
accessible to the masses, particularly in rural areas.

further illustrates the significant urban–rural disparity in coverage. Since the majority (69%) of 
people in Punjab resides in rural areas8 where coverage is low, an overall improvement in 
Punjab’s health indicators will not be visible unless attention is given to raise coverage in rural 
areas.
