11.  Although all the above indicators are unacceptably low, perhaps the most worrisome is 
the low proportion of women delivering babies in health facilities, particularly in rural areas. A 
recent article9 highlights the importance of institutional deliveries and the risk of delivering at 
home, even by a skilled birth attendant, since there is a limit to what a skilled person can do in a 
home. 
12.  It is critical for policy makers and program implementers to start thinking of ways of 
encouraging institutional deliveries if MDG5 is to be achieved. At least addressing institutional 
barriers—such as the unavailability of women medical officers (WMOs), gynecologists, lady 
health visitors, and midwives; and ensuring privacy at labor rooms, physical standards, and 
availability of equipment and supplies—could be a starting point by the Health Department.   
13.  Nutritional Status of Children. Malnutrition among children is identified as a major 
underlying condition that predisposes children to fatal diseases, leading to high mortality. The 
prevalence of 34% malnutrition in Punjab is higher than the threshold of the World Health 
Organization (WHO) to call it a serious public health problem.  
14.  Health Awareness and Basic Hygiene Practices. One of the major causes of child 
mortality is diarrhea, which can be prevented with simple basic hygiene practices. In Punjab, 
only 41% of households reported using soap to wash their hands before eating food and 55% 
after using toilets.

private sectors. The public sector consists of primary care facilities including 188 maternal and 
child  health  centers,  2,456  basic  health  units  (BHUs),  293  rural  health  centers  (RHCs); 
secondary  care  facilities  including  77  tehsil  headquarter  hospitals  (THQs)  and  35  district

16.  The  major  causes of underutilization  of  the public sector  are  unavailability  of staff,

17.  Private Sector. The private sector is concentrated in urban areas, and generally offers 
curative care through small private office-based clinics. There are some 46 private hospitals in 
Punjab, with a range of 10 to over 100 beds, including small maternity homes with very basic 
equipment. Considering Punjab’s 35 districts and the number of private hospitals in big cities, 
these statistics are a gross underestimate of the actual number of private hospitals in the 
province. The private sector also includes pharmacies and non-pharmacy retail outlets from 
where, more often than not, an unqualified dispenser sells all kinds of prescription and over-the-
counter drugs.13    
18.  Referral System. The referral system is extremely weak and largely self-directed. For 
effective service delivery related to the MNCH services, it is essential that all services from 
community level to DHQs are linked in a chain of referral. An effective referral system is 
particularly critical when it comes to emergency obstetric care where efficient referral and 
effective handling of the referred case can prevent maternal death.  
19  Procurement of Drugs. The shortage of drugs in a health facility is a major reason for 
low utilization of the health facilities. The shortage is due to lower budgetary allocation as well 
as an inefficient procurement and drug-testing procedure.   
4.  Health Human Resources  
20.  To implement MNCH-related MSDS successfully, there is a critical need to have an 
adequate number of health workers (particularly WMOs, midwives, nurses, lady health visitors, 
and paramedics) with adequate skills in addressing the health needs of mother and child. 
Currently, about 22% of the approved posts for various health workers at BHUs and RHCs in 
Punjab are vacant, although GoPb has introduced various incentive schemes and the vacancies 
have been gradually reduced. Among medical staff, the highest proportion (32%) of vacant 
posts14 is for the WMO who is expected to play a critical role in preventing maternal death. 
Similarly, 37% of the approved posts for nurses at BHUs and RHCs are vacant. At DHQs, 
almost one third of the approved posts of gynecologists and anesthetists are vacant. The 
situation is even worst at THQs where 48% of the sanctioned posts for gynecologists and 59% 
for anesthetists are vacant.

B.  Public Health Financial Management  
1.  Public Financial Management in Theory  
32.  The  budget,  as  a  management  tool  for  economic  and  fiscal  planning,  is  the 
communication of a plan for a given period expressed in financial terms, and is a means of 
controlling and monitoring the use of funds. Effective planning of programs and activities should 
precede budget preparation so that the main policy priorities of government can be translated 
into  manageable  components  and  subsequently  costed  to  determine  affordability.  Budget 
preparation should then follow at the end of this process.  
 
33.  Effective budget execution requires on the one hand that spending departments receive 
reliable information on available funds within which they can commit expenditure. This may be 
undermined by poor access to budget during the year and may lead to a downward revision of 
allocations in the revised budget estimates. On the other hand, basic management accounting 
practices throughout the year should enable management to analyze underperforming activities 
and take corrective action accordingly. This relies on the preparation of systematic financial 
reports, and constant checking and verification of the bookkeeping and recording practices of 
budget. Important reconciliations should be undertaken on a regular (daily, weekly, monthly) 
basis  to  ensure  accuracy  in  recording,  reliability  in  reporting,  and  control  to  ensure  that 
adequate checks and balances exist at key points in the system.  
 
34.  The quality of the internal control systems within an organization affects the fiduciary 
environment, hence the efficiency of public spending. Organizations and their systems are 
susceptible to weaknesses and risks, resulting in the possibility of poor performance, error 
and/or abuse. Senior management, therefore, introduces and maintains control procedures to 
ensure that organizational objectives are achieved and public standards are met. Internal audit, 
in turn, relies on the presence of an adequate, effective, and reliable set of internal controls. The 
internal audit department of any organization is an integral part of the management of that 
organization. It can be defined as an independent, objective assurance and consulting activity 
designed  to  add  value  and  improve  an  organization’s  operations.  It  helps  an  organization 
accomplish  its  objectives  by  bringing  a  systematic,  disciplined  approach  to  evaluate  and 
improve the effectiveness of risk management, control, and governance processes. 
 
35.  Unlike  internal  auditors,  external  auditors  are  independent  of  the  organization,  and 
provide an annual opinion on the financial statements. The work of the internal and external 
auditors should be coordinated for optimal effectiveness and efficiency. The primary mission of 
the  external  auditors  is  to  provide  an  independent  opinion  on  the  organization’s  financial 
statements  annually.  Their  approach  is  historical  in  nature,  as  they  assess  whether  the 
statements conform to generally accepted accounting principles, whether they fairly present the 
financial position of the organization, whether the results of operations for a given period are 
accurately represented, and whether the financial statements have been materially affected.

consideration of the links between the two. In the Health Department, incremental budgeting

37.  As access to funds is not smooth throughout the year, departments tend to concentrate 
most of the outlays in the last quarter. The capacity to spend according to allocations also 
remains limited, which may be due to low absorptive capacity and/or poor expenditure planning. 
The latter aspect is particularly severe in the case of the development budget, where poor 
capacity to plan investment projects and the political economy of the annual development 
program result in implementation delays and a substantial part of the development budget is 
carried over to the next year’s budget.  
 
38.  Proper financial management relies on the possibility to analyze the links between policy 
and budgetary allocations. This is currently not possible in the health sector in Punjab. Financial 
management in the province is constrained by widespread unavailability of reliable financial 
information with which to analyze expenditures in the health sector against policy objectives and 
priorities. While plenty of financial data is available, much of it is inconsistent and gives little or 
no indication of how much is spent, where, and on what.  
 
39.  As a result, performance measurement, both physical and financial, is not possible 
because  of  lack  of  an  integrated  and  informed  budget  statement—the  split  between 
nondevelopment and development and between the various separate development initiatives. 
The development budget is not structured using the Project for Improved Financial Reporting 
and Accounting (PIFRA) classifications (although they are broadly similar). Hence, alignment or 
analysis of budgets and expenditures using these codes is not possible, making it difficult to 
identify the flow of public resources into the same sector or program from the two budgets. By 
having appropriate links between the structure of how the budget is prepared and policy goals, 
the Health Department should be able to establish the amount of funds allocated toward a 
certain policy objective. This will require classification of the budget at all levels of the health 
sector on the basis of “policy aligned” subfunctional or program classification codes.

3.  Internal Control  
41.  Internal controls are the various checks and balances set within an organization to 
safeguard  the  integrity  of  expenditure.  They  are  a  critical  part  of  public  expenditure 
management and governance more generally. On the one hand, there is in a formal sense an 
extensive system of internal controls, including well-documented approval processes; numerous 
manuals and guidelines, including the GoPb’s financial rules and regulations, the purchase 
manual,  and  standardized  registers;  a  well-entrenched,  hierarchical,  “approvals  culture  by 
documentation”;  and  an  extensive—albeit  manual—“paper  trail”.  On  the  other  hand,  these 
internal controls are often cumbersome and administratively burdensome. More importantly, 
while the internal controls are in principle generally sound and sensible, they are in practice 
adhered to in a weak and uneven manner. There is limited technical capacity to implement 
procedures in the way envisaged, and weak supervision and enforcement, especially at the 
district government level. However, there are improvements—the PIFRA is streamlining the 
chart  of  accounts  and  financial  management,  and  enabling  quicker  and  more  accurate 
reconciliation of accounting information via an electronic rather than manual system.  
42.  Punjab’s  system  of  internal  controls  against  the  internationally  recognized  internal 
control benchmarks are as follows: 
(i)  Segregation of duties. Segregation of duties does exist in the health sector. For 
example,  in  a  DHQ  hospital  setting,  goods  are  ordered  by  a  medical 
superintendent;  received  and  recorded  by  a  storekeeper;  and  processing  of 
payment against supplier’s invoice is done by the hospital’s accounts staff, which 
is then authorized by the district accounts officer (DAO) to release the payment 
directly in supplier’s bank account. However, in this whole process, the vested 
interest plays its role at almost every stage to defeat the spirit of segregation of 
powers.  
 
(ii)  Effective organizational structures. The current organizational structure does 
not  facilitate  effective,  efficient,  or  transparent  financial  management  and 
financial flows. The existence of national, provincial, and district organizations—
all providing separate aspects, and funding, for health care—is problematic. This 
situation  is  likely  to  be  exacerbated  if  another  layer  at  divisional  level  is 
introduced,  or  certain  tertiary  level  hospitals  returned  to  the  provincial 
government, thus fracturing the referral chain from primary to secondary levels. 
 
(iii)  Appropriate  levels  of  authorization  and  approval  adhered  to.  Rules  on 
delegation of financial powers in Punjab exist, and were revised in 2006 to take

adherence to these approval limits remains an issue. Noncompliance with these 
rules and regulations occurs at both the district and provincial levels. Many of the 
pending  audit  observations  relate  to  the  noncompliance  with  rules  and 
regulations.18 
 
(iv)  Physical  safeguards.  These  are  necessary  to  protect  personnel,  assets, 
systems,  and  records.  In  the  Health  Department,  management  review  and 
monitoring of assets does not take place in a systematic manner, nor controls 
provided by external audit, which is confined to the audit of financial statements 
only. Under current arrangements, the payroll function (preparation of payroll 
budgets, payment of salaries, posting of costs to the PIFRA system, etc.) is a 
function of the DAO’s office, with the obligation on the drawing and disbursement 
officers in each line department to notify the DAO of any changes in personnel. 
Under these shared responsibilities, there is little to prevent (or even detect at a 
later date) a drawing and disbursement officer from retaining the salary paid for a 
member of staff who has left the service.   
 
(v)  Management review and monitoring. Under the present arrangements, there is 
little evidence, if any, of monitoring to ensure that personnel understand the 
systems,  processes,  procedures,  and  activities  established  by  management. 
Expenditure  management  and  tracking  is  missing  across  the  whole  system. 
Mostly, time is spent on budget preparation, execution, and recording of financial 
information in the prescribed books of accounts. Arrangements exist wherein the 
drawing and disbursement officers reconcile their expenditure with the DAO on a 
monthly basis. This is the only form of reconciliation that takes place at the 
district  level.  There  is  little,  if  any,  analytical  or  diagnostic  work—including 
variance accounting—so it is not possible for the Government to satisfy itself that 
expenditures are being allocated or aligning with its core priorities.   
 
(vi)  Accounting and arithmetical controls. These exist only in the DAO’s office at 
district level and in the Accountant General’s Office for provincial expenditures. 
There is very limited adherence, at any level in the health sector, to statutory and 
other professional requirements to maintain proper accounts, ledger balances, 
and reconciliation procedures; and to ensure transactions are correctly recorded 
and processed. 
 
(vii)  Appropriate  personnel  and  staffing  levels.  The  numbers  and  levels  of 
approved  staffing  positions  responsible  for  financial  management  are  poorly 
allocated between province and district. However, it is clear that the technical 
capacity and professional qualifications of staff remain a challenge. Particularly at 
the district government level, there is a noticeable absence of trained or qualified 
accounting  officials  and/or  internal  auditors  to  manage  and  supervise 
expenditures and procurement.    
 
(viii)  Effective supervision of controls and systems. Reliance on pre-audit and 
external audit as substitutes for internal controls has increased fiduciary risk at all 
levels of government in Punjab. Internal audit remains very weak, especially at 
district levels.

4.  Internal Audit  
42.  International accounting standards dictate that any organization should have effective 
internal audit. The internal audit function is an integral part of the organization’s management 
and it is based on the presence of an adequate, effective, and reliable set of internal controls. 
The findings and recommendations included in a standard internal audit report are reported to 
the management of the organization, which should then act upon these recommendations. 
Subsequent internal audits would begin with previous recommendations and whether or not 
management has acted in response. Internal audit work can, and often is, relied upon by 
external  auditors  to  help  target  the  time-limited  external  audit  to  areas  of  greatest  control 
weakness and to avoid duplication. 
43.  In the health sector and in Punjab in general, the internal audit function is not effective. 
Although  the  internal  audit  wing  in  the  Health  Department  exists,  the  director  and  deputy 
director posts are vacant. The “confidential” nature of the internal audit reports, unclear role and 
direction of the internal audit wing, its reporting line to the additional secretary for establishment, 
and the absence of any training for the audit team are symptoms of the poor effectiveness of the 
internal audit function in the health sector.  
44.  At the district government level, the internal audit function is non-existent. Although 
mandated  by  the  Punjab  Local  Government  Ordinance  (PLGO),  very  few  nazims  (district 
mayors) have appointed internal auditors. There is, from the part of the district governments’ 
bureaucracy, a generalized mistrust toward the internal audit function mostly because it reports 
to the nazim. This is in fact a flaw in the PLGO since the internal auditor should report to the 
district coordination officer as the chief executive of the district. This problem is compounded by 
the lack of clear terms of service and job descriptions for the internal auditors, which make their 
appointment even more controversial. According to some GoPb officials, in those few cases 
where an internal auditor has been appointed by nazims, patronage has prevailed with little 
regard to the professional qualifications of the appointee.  
5.  External Audit  
45.  The auditor general of Pakistan is responsible for external audit of both the provincial 
and district governments. Both provincial and district director generals for audit offices conduct 
systematic external audit of provincial and district governments’ entities. They mostly perform 
financial audit, but in the case of the provincial office, risk-based audit and performance audit of 
selected functions of selected spending agencies is also carried out. The external audit also 
comprises a compliance testing with internal controls for a given institution and this is reportedly 
one of the high-risk areas for many institutions within the Health Department. Based on the audit 
observations raised by the director general for audit, the Health Department should convene the 
Departmental Accounts Committee, which is chaired by the secretary, to address the audit 
observations  raised  by  the  external  audit.  It  is  not  clear,  however,  to  what  extent  the 
Departmental Accounts Committee is regularly convened and audit observations cleared. A 
similar situation is found at the district governments’ level, where there is poor follow-up on 
external audit observations.

sector is effectively reformed to make good quality MNCH services accessible to the masses in 
Punjab. Apart from technical improvements of health workers, and physical health facilities,

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
Pakistan’s health indicators are the worst among South Asian countries. For instance, Pakistan’s infant mortality rate 
(IMR) is 78 compared to 57 in India and 46 in Nepal. Poor people have the worst health outcomes. They are pushed 
further into poverty because of ill health, resulting in lower productivity or loss of daily wages, and the burden of health 
care  expenditure.  Pakistan  rightly  recognizes  the  importance  of  improving  health  outcomes  (i.e.,  health  sector 
investments) as an important part of the Government’s poverty alleviation plan (Pakistan’s national health policy 2001).  
 
Pakistan, especially Punjab, has demonstrated strong commitment to achieving the Millennium Development Goals 
(MDGs), and actively monitoring the MDG indicators. The health care budget has increased substantially in the last few 
years. Despite these efforts, Punjab is unlikely to achieve the MDG targets for reduction of the maternal mortality ratio 
(MMR) and IMR without extra efforts and reforms in health service delivery, while it may achieve all other MDGs. 
 
The Punjab Millennium Development Goals Program intends to improve health services delivery by improving quality 
and standards of health care, increasing public health financing, improving the efficiency of public health financing, and 
institutional management of health service delivery. The country partnership strategy 2007–2011, which is being 
finalized, includes support for reforms to address governance and institutional bottlenecks leading to improved delivery 
of inclusive social services.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: TI-M 
1.  Key Issues  
 
The majority of maternal and infant deaths in Punjab are preventable if women and children have timely access to 
quality preventive, primary, and secondary health care. Access is limited or delayed because health services are not 
physically available in their neighborhood, doctors and/medicines are not available, or services are unaffordable. Even 
if health care services are available, their quality is not always optimal. Punjab’s health service delivery system needs 
quantitative and qualitative improvements, and measures to reduce the burden of health care expenditure on the poor.  
 
Private practitioners are prevalent, but in rural areas they are often quacks and unskilled birth attendants. Qualified 
private health care is more expensive than public health care. Thus, it is essential to improve public primary and 
secondary health care, if Punjab is to reduce the IMR and MMR among the poor.  
 
The poor quality of public primary and secondary health is mainly due to historical under-financing of health care in 
Pakistan. Pakistan’s per capita public health expenditure is the lowest in South Asia. It spends only about $9 per 
person, against the $30–$40 recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) for developing countries. In 
addition, the limited resources have not been utilized cost-effectively. Until 2 years ago, the majority of the health care 
budget of the government of Punjab went to tertiary health care, which mainly serves the urban population and whose 
benefits are known to be regressively distributed.  
 
2. Design Features 
 
(i)  The Program is aimed at improving maternal, neonatal, and child (MNCH) services for rural areas, where 
social indicators are worse than those urban areas. Availability of health services is a major problem in 
rural areas. 
(ii)  The Program focuses on primary and secondary health care, whose benefits are more progressively 
distributed than those of tertiary health care. 
(iii)  The Program supports health cards that will target the bottom 30% of pregnant women, in accordance 
with the present plan, although the plan has to be detailed and tested first.

major groups affected. 
 
Better primary and secondary health services will lead to better health of the populations and lead to increased 
productivity. In addition, affordable health services available for the poorer segment of the population will prevent them 
from falling deeper into poverty. 
 
1.  Discuss the impact of the policy reform(s) on vulnerable groups and ways to address it/them (refer to social

The health sector reforms are especially focused on women and children in rural areas who cannot afford proper private 
health care. They are the most vulnerable populations in Punjab.  
 
2.  Discuss how the policy reform(s) contribute(s) to poverty reduction, pro-poor growth, and the MDGs. 
  
The entire program is to attain health MDGs 4 and 5.. A sustainable health care financing system to be designed by 
2011 will pool the health risks of the rich and the poor, and let the rich compensate for the poor. This  will mitigate 
burden of health care expenditure on the poor.    
 
II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
The main beneficiaries are pregnant women and young children in rural areas. Secondary beneficiaries are other 
residents of rural areas who use public health facilities. As discussed above, these beneficiaries tend to come from 
poorer households, as the better off choose private practitioners for curative care. Causes of disparity in access to 
health services or other social in services in Punjab is (i) residence—either rural or urban, (ii) gender, and (iii) economic 
status.  
 
B.  Consultation and Participation 
1.  Provide a summary of the consultation and participation process during the project preparation. 
 
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) team consulted with a wide range of government staff both in the provincial and 
district governments, and health workers at primary and secondary health care facilities, federal health programs, 
Punjab Medical and Dentistry Association, and other development partners. The team also consulted with a group of 
lady health workers who work in the beneficiaries’ community. Although systematic consultation with beneficiaries was 
not conducted, the team reviewed the studies based on survey and focus group meetings among the beneficiaries.
